In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Julia's string processing capabilities are quite powerful. Here is how you can write a function `clean_column` that performs the specified clean-up on column names:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    # Lowercase the string
    lc_col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    strip_col = strip(lc_col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    clean_col = replace(strip_col, r"[-\\s]" => "_")
    
    return clean_col
end

# Example usage:
original_names = ["My Column", "your-column", "His  Column"]
clean_names = map(clean_column, original_names)
println(clean_names)
```

This function takes an `AbstractString` as input and returns a clean version of the column name. It first lowercases the string, then strips any leading or trailing whitespaces, and finally replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores. The output is a vector containing the cleaned column names.
